summary: Internal Deutsche Bank compliance email chain from 2013 discussing the clearance of alerts related to onboarding Jeffrey Epstein as a client. AML Compliance clears negative reputation alerts based on senior management approval and distinguishes the client from another Jeffrey Epstein with a different middle name and residence. The accounts are to be opened in the names of companies he controls.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Prospective client of Deutsche Bank's Asset & Wealth Management division; subject of RDC (reputation) and PCR alerts which are being cleared by compliance to allow account opening.

persons.name: Andrew J. Kisz
persons.context: Author of the final clearance email, stating AML Compliance clears the alerts against Jeffrey Epstein based on senior management approval and distinguishing him from another individual.

persons.name: Chip Packard
persons.context: Cited as providing email approval, stating he does not believe there is any reputational risk in taking on Jeffrey Epstein as a client.

persons.name: Kirby
persons.context: Forwarded an internal email regarding the clearance of alerts for Jeffrey Epstein.

connections.description: Packard, as senior management, approved onboarding Epstein as a client despite negative reputation alerts, indicating a business relationship.
Kisz, as AML Compliance Officer, formally cleared compliance alerts, facilitating Epstein's onboarding as a bank client.

events.title: RDC and PCR Alerts Generated
events.description: Deutsche Bank's compliance systems generated alerts pertaining to negative reputation information on prospective client Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Internal Clearance Request
events.description: Internal email requests clearance for Jeffrey Epstein, noting accounts will be opened in names of companies he controls and citing Chip Packard's approval.

events.title: Final AML Clearance Granted
events.description: Andrew J. Kisz formally clears all alerts, allowing Deutsche Bank to proceed with opening accounts for Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: Deutsche Bank AML Compliance cleared negative reputation alerts for Jeffrey Epstein in 2013 based on senior management (Chip Packard) approval.
The bank planned to open accounts not in Jeffrey Epstein's name, but in the names of two companies he controlled, to mitigate perceived reputational risk.
Compliance distinguished their client, Jeffrey E. Epstein of NY/FL, from a Jeffrey S. Epstein of Massachusetts to clear some alerts as false positives.
The document reveals internal processes where business interests overrode compliance flags regarding a high-risk client with a known negative reputation.
